p: Different spatial scales have been used in geographical analyses to identify the drivers of human risk from WNV infections. The most commonly used spatial scale in the United States is counties [ 17, 22, 31], census tracts or Zip Code Tabulation Areas (ZCTA) [ 12, 32], census block groups [ 33], and buffers of varying sizes around trap locations or human cases [ 24]. Each of these spatial scales has its own inherent biases, as these political boundaries do not necessarily correspond to the ecological processes of the disease in question [ 34]. Alternatively, dividing the area into equal spaces, such as rectangular bins or hexagons, has been used to reduce some of these biases (e.g. [ 35]). Hexagonal grids have an additional advantage in that they reduce the edge effects, better fit curved surfaces, and have identical neighbors [ 36, 37].
